title-group.article-title: Bone bridge resection for correction of distal radial deformities after partial growth plate arrest: two cases and surgical technique

abstract.p: Partial closure of the growth plate is an uncommon complication in the distal radius even though distal radial fractures are among the most common injuries in children. We report two cases of resection of a bony bridge in the distal radial growth plate in boys aged 8 and 9 years with a description of the operative technique.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Distal radial fractures are amongst the most common injuries in children (Peterson and Peterson, 1972; Peterson et al., 1994; Worlock and Stower, 1986) with approximately 15% involving the distal radial epiphysis (Mizuta et al., 1987). Despite this high incidence, post-traumatic distal radial growth arrest is uncommon, with an estimated incidence of 1% to 7% (Bragdon, 1965; Davis and Green, 1976; Lee et al., 1984). Although resection of bone bridges with the insertion of interpositional materials is a common method of treatment for growth arrest in the lower extremity (Bright, 1974; Langenskiöld, 1981; 1993), it is less commonly used in the upper extremity. To our knowledge, only four cases of resection of a bony bridge of the distal radial growth plate have been described (Waters et al., 2002; Williamson and Staheli, 1990). We report two clinical cases, with a description of the operative technique, and a review of previous publications.

sec.title: Case 1
sec.p: A right-handed 6-year-old boy sustained a closed distal radius injury after falling on the outstretched right arm in August 2002 while abroad. Plain radiographs at the time indicated a Salter–Harris type II epiphyseal fracture of the distal radius (Figure 1A). He was treated with a cast for 6 weeks but did not receive any orthopaedic care after his return home from vacation. After a minor injury involving the wrist in 2005 (3 years later) new radiographs revealed a 10° palmar tilt, 0° radial slope and 5 mm shortening of the distal radius in relation to the distal ulna with suspicion of an abnormal growth plate (Figure 1B). MRI confirmed the presence of a central radially inclined physeal bony bridge (Figure 1C) involving 15% of the growth plate surface (Figure 1D). He underwent a resection of the bony bridge with interposition of cement without an epiphysiodesis of the distal ulna in June 2005 (Figure 1E,F,G). Evidence of growth with diminution of shortening of the distal radius was observed radiologically 3 months postoperatively. There was no recurrence during the next 4 years (Figure 1H) but after 5 years follow-up a positive ulnar index of +3 mm was noted (Figure 1I) with an associated nonunion of the ulnar styloid that was not visible at operation. Clinically, the patient was asymptomatic with normal and symmetrical wrist and forearm mobility.

(G) Postoperative posteroanterior view with cement interposition. (H) AP view after 4 years follow-up. (I) AP view after 5 years follow-up.

sec.title: Case 2
sec.p: A right-handed 7-year-old boy suffered from a Salter–Harris type I injury of the right distal radius. This fracture was complicated by a partial growth arrest with a positive ulnar index of the distal radius and a nonunion of the ulnar styloid (Figure 2A). He was treated by resection of the bridge and interposition of a silastic tendon spacer at the age of 8 years. At skeletal maturity, 7 years later, there was no radiological evidence of recurrence with radiographs showing the change in position of the silastic spacer, reflecting growth of more than 5 cm (Figure 2B,C). Clinically, he was asymptomatic with a normal physical examination.

sec.title: Surgical technique
sec.p: The surgical technique we used was first described by Langenskiöld in 1967 in the upper end of the tibia (Langenskiöld, 1993). This technique consists of resecting the bony bridge that is causing the epiphysiodesis and replacing it by a ‘plug’ made of inert material.

Preoperative planning for surgical excision of the bony bridge includes a history, physical examination, plain radiographs of the wrist, bone age films, MRI and making a diagram or map that defines the bar in the growth plate (Carlson and Wenger, 1984). For bridge resection to be effective, a cement or silastic plug must be introduced between the metaphysis and the epiphysis into the epiphyseal plate, replacing the bony bridge. The operative procedure is difficult and requires full information about the site of the epiphysiodesis. A posterior surgical approach is used with a longitudinal skin incision centred on the growth plate. Exposure of the lesion can be obtained via the fourth dorsal compartment by retracting the tendon of the extensor digitorum laterally and by resecting Lister’s process. The osseous bridge is resected through a posterior metaphyseal window made at a safe distance from the growth plate. We used a set of fine curettes and shavers to ensure complete removal of the bridge. The bridge is removed piece by piece under fluoroscopic control until the presumably healthy cartilage can be seen all around it. The material used for plugging was different in each of the two cases according to the preference of each surgeon. Postoperative care, in the absence of a concomitant osteotomy, does not require a cast thus permitting immediate joint mobilization.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Although epiphyseal injuries are usually free of serious complications, partial or total growth arrest may occur occasionally (Mizuta et al., 1987; Peterson et al., 1994). Partial arrest of the growth plate is particularly liable to produce progressive angular deformation when a bridge of sclerotic bone forms eccentrically between the epiphyseal ossification centre and the metaphyseal bone. The partial arrest retards normal growth in a variable fashion, but angular, longitudinal or horizontal deformities may occur for as long as growth continues (Bright, 1974). Resection of the bridge, coupled with the insertion of various implants, is an attractive option for alleviating this problem (Bright, 1974; Carlson and Wenger, 1984; Inoue et al., 2006; Langenskiöld, 1981; Williamson and Staheli, 1990). These procedures have been reported to be clinically beneficial in 60–84% of cases of partial growth arrest (Bright, 1974; Waters et al., 2002). Experimental and clinical studies have established several principles: the osseous bridge must be completely resected; interposition materials must be used to prevent recurrence; and the approach must directly lead to and be as close as possible to the area of the bony bar (Bright, 1974; Langenskiöld, 1981; 1993; Lee et al., 1993; Vickers, 1980).

This surgical technique is less discussed in relation to the management of distal radial growth arrest for several reasons. Premature closure of the growth plate after distal radial epiphyseal fractures is extremely rare, even though distal radial fractures are among the most common injuries in children (Abram and Thompson, 1987; Davis and Green, 1976; Lee et al., 1984; Valverde et al., 1996). The diagnosis is usually made when the patient is too old, therefore reducing the potential for bone growth and remodelling postoperatively. The patients are also often too old because nearly 70% of patients with an epiphyseal injury are more than 12 years old (Bragdon, 1965; Davis and Green, 1976; Mizuta et al., 1987). The prolonged time interval between the injury and the intervention further complicates the situation and usually does not allow correct surgical management. Waters et al. (2002) described a mean time interval of 37 months between the time of injury and the time of surgery. The advantages and disadvantages of this procedure are unknown because only a few authors have described their experiences on bridge resection specifically for distal radial growth arrest but the surgical technique was not described (Bronfen et al., 1994; Langenskiöld, 1981; Waters et al., 2002; Williamson and Staheli, 1990).
After having reviewed the relevant papers in addition to our own experience, we recommend the following indications for the treatment of growth arrest in the distal radius by bone bridge resection:

list-item.p: Central bony bridge involving less than 50% of the area of the growth plate
Age younger than 10 years in girls and 12 years in boys

sec.p: The growth in the distal radius rapidly decreases during the last 2 years of growth with a residual capacity of 1 cm between the ages of 13 and 15 in girls and 15 and 17 years in boys (Pritchett, 1988). This procedure should therefore not be used in girls over the age of 13 years and in boys over the age of 15. Between 10 and 13 years in girls, and 12 and 15 in boys, other options listed below should be discussed.

An associated radial osteotomy to correct existing angular deformity or an ulnar epiphysidodesis to improve the radio ulnar variance should not be done in young children at the time of bridge resection. We have observed correction of the radial slope after bridge resection without a concomitant osteotomy or epiphysiodesis. Possible associated TFCC lesions and nonunions of the ulnar styloid after high energy injuries should be assessed by MRI. If such lesions are present, the surgeon should proceed with resection of the ulnar styloid and reinsertion of the TFCC (Abid et al., 2008; Terry and Waters, 1998).

For girls and boys older than 10 and 12 years respectively, other options such as epiphysiodesis, corrective osteotomy or distraction osteogenesis by callotasis are available, depending on the residual growth potential. Complete radial and ulnar epiphysiodesis combined with an additional ulnar shortening if the radioulnar variance is markedly positive is an effective procedure (Hove and Engesaeter, 1997; Waters et al., 2002). However, discrepancy in forearm length can produce a cosmetic problem, especially when the difference is 3 cm or more; Lengthening by callotasis with a circular external fixator should then be preferable (Page and Szabo, 2009). Correction by callotasis may also be a good alternative if the bone bridge involves more than 50% of the area of the growth plate or if a previous bone bridge resection has failed. However, it must be understood that this is a long and often tedious process for both the patient and the surgeon. Waiting and then correcting the deformity by carrying out an osteotomy when the growth has finished may also be an option, but not for girls and boys aged less than 10 and 12 years respectively because of the prognosis for severe length discrepancy between the radius and ulna.

Risk factors for the development of growth arrest include high-energy injuries involving the growth plate, compression injuries, multiple traumatic attempts to reduce displaced epiphyseal fractures and late attempts at epiphyseal fracture reduction. For these reasons, many authors recommend that reductions of epiphyseal fracture be carried out urgently and in gentle fashion using sedation and/or general anaesthesia. Knowing the potential for bone remodelling in younger patients and the absence of a connection between post-reduction angulation and the development of a premature epiphysiodesis (Davis and Green, 1976), further attempts at reduction should be avoided. In patients with injuries to the growth plate follow-up until skeletal maturity is required. The reason for the prolonged follow-up period is that growth arrest may develop up to 10 years after wrist injuries (Fodden, 1992; Ogden, 1987). As was seen in the first case, follow-up is necessary while growth continues because we noted a recurrence 5 years after the initial surgery.
